But all that said and out of the way, this show is not as it would appear by its cover alone. Ironically, despite the above being major pet peeves of mine, another is what i have come to dubthe "Satsuki Kiryuin" (Antagonist from Kill la Kill) Syndrome of high school plots. That in which the school president is always a female and controls more power than most mafioso bosses would care to brag about in public. Under which of course, all the boys are powerless to defend themselves or their dignity. I'm all for strong female characters, but this trope is so exhausted at this point it completely lacks any mental flavour. Fortunately, we're given hints to the humanity Satsuki Kiryuin of Busou Shoujo' a lot sooner than is typical of this character archetype, making her feel much more like a person.


Thankfully, this show's main character comes from the Kazi no Stigma school of thought; where not only is he also a competent badass himself, but is also not afraid to duke it out with the ladies. A welcome tangent from the tired cliché's of contemporary chivalry we're saturated with these days. That's not to say he isn't a gentlemen when he feels like it, but the mix of minor narcissism and ego is a welcome ingredient we don't get enough of from our average MC's.


Unfortunately, beyond the primary protagonist and antagonist the show unashamedly falls into some expected tropes, you could literally cut and paste the supporting characters from "Hundred" and been none the wiser. It is sad when a character exists purely on the merit of their cuteness, but this is part and parcel of a harem plot i suppose and i can only say it doesn't exactly fail in its intentions so i can't mark it down too much.


There's really not too much to be said about the story itself, it's a fair foundation for the concept, i suppose "if it aint broke, don't fix it" applies here. Starting fresh in a new school environment is a common fantasy of many of us, even if it isn't original it is universally relatable; as is, for guys, getting into lewd situations with the ladies.


One certainly can't really complain about the art either, it is more than sufficient with a pleasant attention to detail. In a way that is a skill in and of itself for the artist. Knowing where to invest your time and talents, the detail is exactly where it's needed, when it's needed and i can really appreciate that as a viewer.


There is a certain element of parody/irony involved as far as the humour is concerned which i can also fondly appreciate. It's not really a part of the story per se and frankly speaking the story could be a lot better if it really wanted to to make the show a real piece of art, but it's doing an adequite job of supporting the characters to get the basics in and the humour is just a bonus for enjoyment.

But i suppose intent is irrelevant, and i will only consider the things i felt while watching.  Structurally, the show alternates between twomodes, the serious battles and the tropy, goofy slice of life.  In that sense it is reminiscent of Full Metal Panic, though the "serious" is much less serious.   During the fights you'll have freeze-frames with "epic" calligraphic move names being printed on the screen. I find it a very satisfying way to bring the "dere" out of these heroines.  I can also just imagine some fat feminist dyke watching this and getting upset over how problematic it is, and it only makes my metaphorical patriarchal boner harder.  The girls themselves are usually pretty lovable, though not very original.  One of them is a bear, by the way, and yes, the bear gets lewd.

Overall, a harmless, entertaining anime with good visuals and comedic elements.  Recommended viewing for all misogynists.

Busou Shoujo Machiavellianism is an interesting anime. It follows the tried-and-true school setting, but still manages to put an at least somewhat unique twist on the genre, with a few hints of originality here and there. It's hardly a masterpiece, but for some reason I couldn't bring myself to dislike this show.
The story isn't anything special. Troublesome boy attempts to escape a matriarchal academy by defeating sword-wielding girls in combat. I'm sure everyone who watched Prison School got a somewhat nostalgic feel from this show, though the tones differ between the two shows.
With such a simple storyline, Machiavellianism is forced to lean on the strengthof its characters to pull the story forward. Most of the actual swordswomen aren't anything special (with the exceptions being Amou, and perhaps Satori), as they primarily serve to be introduced into our MC's harem.


Nomura himself, however, is an easily likeable character. It's refreshing to see an MC take charge of situations and stand up for himself, rather than wet himself at the sight of a semi-naked women and blabber on about "misunderstandings". Plus, the show manages to incorporate Nomura's carefree, lax attitude into combat scenes themselves, solidifying Nomura as one of the better characters this season had to offer.


The fights themselves also offer an odd twist. Each character has a unique sort of fighting style, challenging Nomura to adapt to each one during his many confrontations. Some fights manage to do a good job of keeping you hooked and entertained (Satori, Warabi), while others tend to bore you with a certain lack of depth (Kikakujo). It's hit or miss, and the darts are all over the board.


The sound is, surprisingly, very well done. A militaristic/regal use of trumpets and violins is incorporated, and manages to get you pretty hyped for what's to come. The OP is pretty damn catchy, too.


The animation is fairly decent. What you would expect from a twelve-episode show.


In the end, this show is a tweener. Hard to love, but equally hard to hate. Personally, I found myself getting excited for episodes, though the final few episodes do fall a tad flat. Like I said, it's hit or miss.


If you're looking for a show with a badass MC, cute girls, and an easy to follow storyline, then this show is right up your alley. If not, hey, that's cool— the bottomless pit of school anime is right around the corner. Thanks for reading.
